title: Obviously Awesome: Product Positioning That Actually Works
description: April Dunford, bestselling author of Obviously Awesome and positioning expert, shares her methodology for nailing product positioning. Learn how to identify competitive alternatives, find differentiated value, target best-fit customers, and craft market-winning strategies that resonate with buyers.
summary: April explains positioning as defining how your product is the best solution for a specific set of companies who care about your unique value. She breaks down the 5-step framework: identify competitive alternatives (including status quo), determine differentiated capabilities, translate to value, identify target customers, and define market category. She emphasizes that weak positioning impacts the entire sales pipeline, from initial interest to post-sale churn. Good positioning feels obvious to the right buyer and requires alignment across marketing, product, sales, and customer success.

key_themes.theme: Positioning Framework: 5 Steps to Market Dominance
key_themes.description: Identify competitive alternatives, determine differentiated capabilities, translate to customer value, identify best-fit customers, define market category
Weak positioning causes confusion in early pipeline, sluggishness in middle stages, and churn after sale when expectations don't match reality

key_themes.theme: Status Quo is Your Real Competitor
key_themes.description: 40% of B2B deals are lost to 'no decision' - companies staying with spreadsheets, status quo, or current solutions

key_themes.theme: Great Positioning Feels Obvious and Simple
key_themes.description: When positioning is right, it becomes transparent - buyers think 'of course that's what it is, what else could it be?'
Requires alignment across marketing, product, sales, customer success, and CEO - cannot be siloed to marketing department
B2B companies segment on firmographics and usage patterns, not demographics - champion persona matters most in buying process

key_themes.theme: Early Stage Products Need Loose Positioning
key_themes.description: New products should keep positioning loose initially, allowing market to pull them in directions they didn't expect

key_insights.quote: Positioning defines how your product is the best in the world, delivering some value that a well-defined set of companies care a lot about.
key_insights.insight: Positioning is about being best for a specific set of buyers who value your unique capabilities, not being best for everyone

key_insights.quote: Weak positioning gets you all the way across the pipeline. Weak positioning hurts you in the early stages... you get this sluggishness in the middle... and then sometimes... you close a lot of deals, but then people churn out on you.
key_insights.context: How weak positioning manifests in business metrics
key_insights.insight: Weak positioning is hard to measure because it shows up as multiple different problems - confusion, sales friction, and post-sale churn

key_insights.quote: In B2B we lose about 40% of our deals to quote-unquote 'no decision,' which actually means we lost to the spreadsheet, we lost to pen and paper, we lost to interns.
key_insights.insight: Status quo (keeping current processes) is your biggest competitor - better than losing to direct competitors

key_insights.quote: When positioning is working really well, it feels like magic and really great positioning feels obvious. You pitch it to people and they're like, 'Well, of course that's it. What else could it be?'
key_insights.context: Describing what good positioning looks like
key_insights.insight: Good positioning becomes invisible - it feels natural and inevitable to the right buyer

key_insights.quote: The founder has an idea what the positioning is, but then you go to the marketing department and it's a little bit different... then you sit in on the sales pitch and that's a little bit different again... so I think a lot of weak positioning comes from the fact that we don't have perfect alignment across the team.
key_insights.insight: Most positioning problems stem from misalignment across functions, not wrong strategy

key_insights.quote: If we're going to fix this thing, we can't just have the marketing department... sit down and cook up new positioning... it actually needs to be a group effort. It's a team sport.
key_insights.insight: Positioning must be built collaboratively with marketing, product, sales, customer success, and CEO in the same room

key_insights.quote: I start with competitive alternatives. What do I got to beat in order to win a deal, status quo, things on the short list. Once I've got that, then I can make a list of differentiated capabilities... then translate those capabilities into value... these things will theme out. So I'll end up with two, three value themes.
key_insights.insight: Start positioning with competitive analysis, then move to differentiation and value - never start with market category

key_insights.quote: You can have companies where... nobody knows what it is... but if I'm selling a deeply technical thing to deeply technical buyers, it's okay if your grandmother doesn't understand what it is. What matters is, does it resonate for your buyers?
key_insights.insight: Positioning doesn't need to be understood by everyone - it only needs to resonate with your target buyer

key_insights.quote: Better for a small company is not the same thing as better for a large enterprise. Your trick in the positioning is to be able to articulate, why are we the best kind of solution for this particular type of customer?
key_insights.insight: 'Better' means different things to different segments - position as best for YOUR specific customer type, not universally

key_insights.quote: Positioning is a fundamental input to messaging. Most of the time when people say messaging, what they mean is this is the text on the homepage... but positioning's all about defining that and then things flow out of that.
key_insights.insight: Positioning comes first and informs all messaging - you can't write copy until you understand your competitive position

key_insights.quote: I think in the early days of a product to keep the positioning a little bit loose and allow the market to pull you maybe in a direction that you didn't think it was going to.
key_insights.insight: Young products should keep positioning flexible - over-tightening too early prevents discovering better markets

key_insights.quote: If I'm selling a consumer thing, maybe all I care about is personas... B2B, everything's a little bit more complicated. Typically we have between five and seven people involved... but the most important persona... is the champion in the account... if our positioning doesn't resonate for that champion, we're dead in the water.
key_insights.context: B2B personas vs consumer and the importance of the champion
key_insights.insight: In B2B deals, the champion persona (person making the short list) matters most - nail positioning for them and they sell internally

key_insights.quote: Help Scout's value is really around delivering amazing customer service that's going to deepen your relationship with the customer. Not everybody cares about that... there are businesses... all they care about is reducing the cost... But... direct to consumer brands or E-commerce brands... see customer service as a way to really drive growth through customer loyalty.
key_insights.context: Help Scout case study - matching value to best-fit customers
key_insights.insight: Differentiated value only matters to specific customer types - identify which segments care deeply about YOUR value

key_insights.quote: Once you start feeling like I got the pattern here, it's starting to come into focus... I've done enough of these pitches now to know if you've got this, this, and this, this pitch is going to go good, and if you don't, it is not... then I think you're ready to really tighten things up.
key_insights.context: Trigger to transition from loose to tight positioning
key_insights.insight: When you see clear patterns in who buys and why, that's your signal to stop experimenting and run hard at that market

key_insights.quote: Most folks will discount the status quo, but they shouldn't because... we lose about 40% of our deals to quote-unquote, 'no decision'... And if we're not positioning well against that, we're never going to get the customer to come off of that.
key_insights.context: Why you must position against status quo
key_insights.insight: Winning deals requires beating the status quo first - direct competitor comparisons only matter if you get past the 'no decision' hurdle
